text: A taxi careens down narrow roadways at breakneck speeds.

In the back seat is WHITTLESLEY. Early 40's, the wreck of handsome man. Unshaven.  Sweat stained.  Rail thin.  Scra arms, a fresh scar on one cheek.  As the taxi roars downh the harbor, Whittlesley leans over the front seat.  (Ital Portuguese to be subtitled)
Faster!  We won't make it.
You want to die? Whittlesley pulls out A KNIFE, puts it to the driver's ju
Do you? Sweat pouring down his brow, the driver re-doubles his sp
The taxi swerves around a corner, nearly crashing into a flies out of sight.

Light rain obscures the bulky outlines of tethered freigh faint laughter leavened with Portuguese phrases, distant from waterfront bars.  One of the smaller boats, the SANT loading as the TAXI fishtails to a halt. Whittlesley gets out, sees the boat still at dock.  His f with relief.
Thank God.

He tosses a handful of bills into the driver's lap, sprin pier as the driver shouts curses after him in Portuguese. shoves past the dock hands as the last load goes onto the The boat's engines churn to life.
I need to speak to the captain! Where is he?
The sailors hold Whittlesley back.
Get your hands off me!  I'm trying to save your lives, you fools!
Several crew members murmur the word "loco".  Hearing the squat man wearing a billed hat and smoking a cigar approa FRANCO.
American?

Yes.  Thank Christ somebody speaks English.  I'm Dr. John Whittlesley. You have some crates of mine on board.  They were shipped by mistake to the Natural History Museum.  We have to get them off the boat.
You have I.D.?
Whittlesley runs a trembling hand through his hair, tryin control and appear reasonable.

No.  Let me explain.  I was on an expedition for the museum on the Upper Xingu.  Something horrible happened.  I'm the only one who got out alive.  I lost everything, my I.D., everything.  I have to make sure no one else dies.  The crates, the crates were sent out before we knew.  There's something unspeakable inside.  If your boat leaves harbor with those crates on board, I can't be responsible.  My God, if they reach New York...
Whittlesley's fists clench spasmodically.  Franco looks t
Loco.
No!  I'm not crazy!  As God is my witness, I'm telling the truth.
Franco barks an order and several sailors grab Whittlesle arms.  They start to lead him back to shore.
Don't do this!  You have to believe me.  Your lives are in danger.
The sailors laugh.  But with an almost super-human streng desperation, Whittlesley throws them off.  He pulls out h
Cash.  Cash, you see?  American money.

Whittlesley throws the money down on the deck.  The breez bills across the bow and all the men, including Captain F scramble for the money, chattering in Portuguese.  While occupied, Whittlesley slips by unnoticed and disappears b

Whittlesley ducks between cages of goats, boxes of farm e movements jerky with panic.  As he continues searching, t moves past him, into the darkness of the hold.  We hear W mumbling between low, ragged breaths.  At the back of the camera finds...  A STACK OF CRATES... clearly labeled NATURAL HISTORY MUSE these as... The CRATES VIBRATE.  The boat has started to Whittlesley stands bolt upright, realizing what's going o
No!

Too late.  He turns to run back on deck but then stops, s A look of desperation fills his eyes.  With one hand he p KNIFE, and unexpectedly puts it to HIS OWN NECK.  Better himself than face what comes next.  The knife touches...

NECKLACE of TWO ARROWS , one gold, another silver. Whittlesley stares wide-eyed into the blackness of the ho start BLEATING in blind panic.  A shaft of moonlight come porthole as the boat turns.  The moonlight falls on THE CRATES.  Whittlesley's eyes lock onto them and he inc them, drawn inexorably closer... closer...
No... no...
He begins mumbling a prayer. MOVE IN ON HIS EYES... filled with dread as he falls to h staring, always staring at THE CRATES...
The crew tends to business and the Santa Lucia points out harbor, disappears into the night.
Squad cars roar down the back roads, sirens flashing.  In the column is an unmarked car.

At the wheel is a strikingly dignified and imposing black a simple, old-fashioned dark suit, narrow black tie, and This is SPECIAL AGENT PENDERGAST, FBI. A BACH SONATA for violin and harpsichord plays on the tap Pendergast hums along as he drives.  A SMALL TOWN COP rid The cop is intimidated both by Pendergast and the morning sweats heavily as he brings Pendergast up to date.

One of the locals found it at dawn. Didn't believe him 'till I saw it myself.  Even then I didn't believe it.  Scared my men shitless.  Me too. I mean... hell... You could smell it a half mile away, Mr. Pendergast.
(unperturbed) Any of your men go on board?
No sir.  No way.  None of us wanted to, I'm the first to admit it.  I said, "Don't get within a mile of this thing.  It's way to big for us. I'm calling the FBI."
Pendergast nods his approval, resumes humming along with particularly intricate harpsichord riff.  As always, the unflappable and totally calm as he drives.

The ocean is still, the air stifling and close.  A hot su on the deck of the SANTA LUCIA.  The boat lists at a craz it has been washed up on the shore.  At first glance, it deserted.  A barrel rolls back and forth as the boat is r successive wave.  We hear sirens approaching and the phal cars pulls up.  Joining them now are TWO AMBULANCES. PENDERGAST gets out along with the others.  All of the co cover their faces, gagging violently at the smell.  Pende once and frowns.  Apart from this, he doesn't react.
(choking) Goin' up-wind if you don't mind.

Pendergast nods.  The cops all fall back in revulsion.  T a safe distance as Pendergast approaches the ghost ship. laced wing-tips sink in the sand.  He leans down, pulls t a time.  He balls both socks, puts them carefully into hi proceeds barefoot towards the boat. Using a piece of driftwood as a plank, Pendergast leans i Santa Lucia.  With surprising agility, he leaps up the pl deck.  At the top he touches a rail.  It's covered in a D LIQUID. BLOOD.  Flies buzz loudly.  A LARGE MACHETE lies abandone Chairs are overturned.  A DEAD GOAT, eviscerated, lies in lifeboat hangs half off the stern.  Pendergast moves aft. watch from the sand below, unwilling to get any closer. hears A DOOR slamming open and closed.  He follows the no sees...  THE DOOR TO THE HOLD.  He approaches, pushes it open and stairwell.  Below deck are BODIES... stacks of them.  They've been TORN TO SHREDS. THE CAMERA MOVES down to one particular man who is neares the stairs.  It's CAPTAIN FRANCO.  His face is frozen in terror.  Flies congregate in the eye sockets.  With his f nudges the body over.  The skull has been torn open.

head_text.subj: THERE IS NO BACK TO FRANCO'S HEAD

text: Silence then we begin hearing sounds of the city... horns construction work. SUPER TITLE... NEW YORK CITY, FOUR MONTHS LATER as we...
NECKLACE of TWO ARROWS , one of gold, the other silver.  The twin to the one seen on Whittlesley.  Widen to...

And the woman wearing the necklace... MARGO GREEN.  She s coffee as she makes notes on several large FOSSILIZED TEE is neatly combed.  No make-up.  She doesn't need it.  She unselfconscious beauty and a mind like a steel trap. At Margo's elbow is a small T.V.  A CNN world news report Margo's New York Times is open to the crossword puzzle, w been doing rapidly, in ink.  Clearly this is a woman who with a mind that can handle more than one thing at a time An alarm on her watch beeps and she fills in the last two crossword puzzle, makes one final note on the fossil spec shuts off the T.V.  She reaches for her back pack and loo CENTRAL PARK with remarkably clear eyes.

HELICOPTER SHOT... Swooping over the fall foliage of the of color and botanical life... The camera picks out MARGO making its way along the winding roads, dodging taxi cabs jeans, a work shirt, a fine blue gabardine jacket with a DOUBLE HELIX PIN.  On her back is a LEATHER BACK PACK whi lap top computer.  She emerges from the park, catches the and rolls up to...

As Margo arrives, the camera moves up and over the buildi rest on the imposing turrets, intersecting roof lines, an arches of the MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY.  This is not an building; it's a 19th century monument to science and man structure fills an entire city block. Happy visitors pour into the museum as Margo takes the im stone steps two at a time.  We hear SCREAMS of pleasure a the normal raucous noises of a large group of THIRD GRADE Margo is amused to find herself surrounded by kids.  Thei MRS. BEASLEY, a stern woman in glasses with a thick New Y calls after them as they all head inside.
Don't run, children!  Stay with your partner and do not run!  If anyone runs they will be sent back to the bus!
Ignoring Mrs. Beasley, TWO BOYS charge past Margo.  HENRY Henry has a buzz cut; Larry has rasta dread knots.  Both old, wear high top sneakers and shorts so big they graze
Henry!  Larry!  What did I just say! You walk right this minute!  Did you hear me?!
Reluctantly, Henry and Larry slow to a rapid race-walk as the huge doorway flanked by two Northwest Coast Indian to Above the doorway WORKMEN are hanging a LARGE BANNER.  It
The school children burst into a three story space domina life-sized statue of a HERD OF ELEPHANTS.  The kids chatt excitement, look up in awe.  Margo nods to a GUARD who sm pins on a plastic I.D.
Morning, Dr. Green.
Morning Joe.  Beautiful day.
Henry watches Margo pass through the turnstiles without p swaggers over.
You work here?
Yes, I do.
What do you do?
(leans down, amused) I'm an Evolutionary Biologist.  What do you do?
Nothing.  I'm in third grade.  What's a revolutionary what ch'a ma' callit?
Evolutionary Biologist.  I study how life on earth evolved over millions of years.
(brightens) Way cool.  Then you know where the dinosaurs are.
Fourth floor, West wing, but stay with your class.

Mrs. Beasley heads into the museum and Larry and Henry me rest of the kids.  Margo turns towards the stairwell, pas IAN CUTHBERT... Museum Director... a pudgy man in wire ri dresses and thinks like a banker.  Hired for his amazing raise money, Cuthbert is one of a new generation of Museu whose focus must always be on the bottom line.
Hello, Ian.  Everything ready for the opening of the Superstition Exhibit?
I'm on my way to get the last piece out of storage right now.
I'd wish you luck but I'm not superstitious.
You will be after tomorrow night.
Cuthbert waves merrily.  A workman uses a LADDER in the s Cuthbert is about to walk under the ladder, stops and car around it instead.  Margo smiles, goes on upstairs.

Cuthbert enters from the lower stairwell.  He is now in o hundreds of areas of the museum that are closed to the th public.  He follows a labyrinthine route down a dim passa with rumbling steam pipes.  There are storage areas on bo labeled ORNITHOLOGY, HERPITOLOGY, CENTRAL ASIA EXPEDITION EXPEDITIONS, WHALE BONE FOSSILS and so on.  Finally Cuthb door marked "WHITTLESLEY EXPEDITIONS 1978-95".  Cuthbert pauses and g but to his surprise the door pushes open.  The lock and d mechanism are both broken off!  Cuthbert frowns.
What the... ?
He goes inside.

Cuthbert flips on a light to see a tall, narrow space.  S shelves reach up into the gloom.  Everywhere we see spear masks, various artifacts.  Ancient tribal costumes lie sh plastic like corpses against the walls.  And in the middl gloom, sitting ominously in the light of a sole hanging b THE WHITTLESLEY CRATES.  The same ones last seen in the h ill-fated Santa Lucia.  They are scattered about in disar particular has been broken open, its contents spread on t Cuthbert mutters in surprise and dismay, kneels by the cr
No, it can't be.

Cuthbert feels gently through the packing material, lets relief as he pulls out a figurine.  It is a small, beauti statue of A MONSTER crouched on all fours. The room falls totally silent as Cuthbert studies THE REL truly frightening piece... massive, razor sharp claws, la nostrils, enormous teeth and red rimmed eyes.  Suddenly C DROP OF BLOOD on his hand!  He's been CUT!
Damn.

Cuthbert rises, shakes his finger in pain.  Blood drips o He pulls out his pocket handkerchief and wraps the wound. handkerchief rapidly soaks through.  Suddenly a HAND CLAM Cuthbert's shoulder!  He's not alone!  He lets out a YELP dropping the Relic and spins to see...  A MUSEUM GUARD standing behind him.  His nameplate reads. He's a gentle young fellow with white blond hair and a ro southern accent.
Beauregard!  You scared me half to death.
I'm sorry, sir.  You okay?
Someone broke into this room.
Anything missin'?
Doesn't look like it.  We're damned lucky.  This statue is priceless.
Cuthbert holds up the RELIC of THE MONSTER.  Beauregard s
Mbwun.  A South American warrior deity.  He carries a powerful curse. Every member of the expedition that found this statue, died.
Beauregard sees Cuthbert's cut finger.
Looks like the curse is still at work.
The claws are sharp... I must have cut myself. (uneasy laugh) Better move these crates to the secure storage area where they'll be safe.
Beauregard studies the door as Cuthbert heads out with th
Don't know if it'll do any good, Mr. Cuthbert.
Why not?
No one broke into this room, sir. Someone broke out.  That lock was torn off from the
inside . Cuthbert glances at the evil face of Mbwun, pales.  As he ON BEAUREGARD, left alone with the crates.

Huge centrifuges, hissing autoclaves, electrophoresis app glowing monitors, elaborate blown-glass distillation colu titration set-ups.  One of the most advanced technical fa its kind.  And mixed in with all the modern machinery are SKELETONS OF ALL KINDS.  Complete homo sapien specimens a around the room.  Standing midst all this is GREGORY KAWA twenties.  Kawakita makes sharp, jerky overhead movements hand, waving something about.  He's practicing casting. zing of a line and the whirring of the fly reel as MARGO whips out, passing right under her nose.
Third from the end!  Right shoulder. Aleut, provenance unknown.
The fly zooms across the room and lights on the shoulder skeleton from the end, labeled "Aleut, provenance unknown rolls her eyes and Kawakita smiles with pride.
If I spent half the time on my Fractal Evolution thesis that I spend on this fly rod, I'd have my PhD.
(small smile) But at what a price.

Kawakita reels in his line as Margo drops her backpack on desk.  An enormous MICROSCOPE stands by the equally impos topped by a tiger skull.  A screen saver of an animated p plays.  Margo unpacks boxes of fossil teeth, hits some ke columns of seemingly indecipherable chemical equations on screen.
I have the species identification on these teeth.  We can extract DNA and start running tests on the extrapolator program.  Call Dr. Frock.  He wanted a demonstration.
Margo, you haven't heard?
What?
Frock's been fired.
Margo straightens, stunned.
That's impossible.
(awkward) I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings, but you know me.  Telegraph. Telephone.  Tell Kawakita.  I got the definitive word from Cuthbert's secretary.  This is Dr. Frock's last week.
Margo is already out the door.

Margo charges through double doors leading into the south She half runs down an elegant, Edwardian fifth-floor corr footsteps lost in the thick carpet.  At the very end is a door bearing a plate entwined with bronze leaves that rea "Dr. Frock".

Margo bursts into the unique office, which is in startlin the modernity of her own.  Two large bow windows look out park.  Upholstered Victorian chairs in a leaf motif sit o carpets featuring large red roses.  Plant specimens and d flora and fauna line the walls.  Cardboard boxes cover th Seated in a wheelchair is a white-haired man in a tweed j loud floral tie.  Glasses slip down his nose. This is DR. FROCK, and he's in the middle of packing.  He smiles apologetically.
Hello, Margo.  Sorry about the mess.
Is it true?  Greg said you'd been fired.
Yes.  Bit of a shock.  But as Cuthbert so tactfully put it, the museum needs new blood.  And since I've been here since the Mesozoic Era --
I don't believe it.
Now Margo, don't overreact.  Cuthbert has to cut costs somehow.  My leaving makes perfect sense.  This isn't exactly early retirement.  I've overstayed the party a bit.
We can't do without you.  You're one of the foremost authorities on primitive pharmacology.  You're practically an institution around here.

That, apparently, is the problem. I'm yesterday's news.  Who needs a Curator of Plant Biology in a museum with one exhibit on plants?  Monsters and dinosaurs, cannibals and shamans are the new currency of the realm.
Frock goes back to his work packing to hide his emotion a moves to his side.  She pulls Frock's books back out of t returns them to his desk.
"Phyletic Transformation and the Tertiary Fern Spike" is not going anywhere.  I'll talk to Cuthbert and put a stop to this right now.
She starts for the door and Frock wheels into her path. first time she sees what he's been carefully hiding... th his eyes.
Please.  Don't humiliate me further.
Let me help.  I can take care of everything.
No, Margo.  This is one problem you can't solve.  You have to stay out of it.  The fact is, I want to retire.
How can you say that?  You know it's not true.
Yes it is.  I'm tired and I'm no longer needed --
My work on fossil intermediates would be crippled without you.
With all due respect, dear, that's bull.  You dance rings around me with your new technology.  You've left me in the dust.
(stubbornly loyal) Your work is highly relevant.  What about your display on Primitive Pharmacology?  Cuthbert told me himself he was going to feature it prominently in the Superstition Exhibit.
Healing plant use among the Ki tribe of Bechuanaland has been cancelled to make room for Tibetan Erotic Art.
Frock reaches out and squeezes her hand gently with a loo the discussion is over.
Come on.  I'll walk you back to the elevator.
I'm not giving up.
You must.
Frock rolls back down the hall the way Margo just came. beside him, downcast.  She's not used to defeat.
This isn't a death sentence.  Greg has promised to teach me fly fishing.  I'll garden.  I'll write.
You are this museum.  It won't be the same without you.
Everyone needs a change of scenery. I've been rolling down these halls for forty-odd years.  That's quite enough.
Margo gets in the elevator reluctantly.  He smiles and me
I'll see you at lunch.
He waves her off merrily.  But once the doors close and M sight, Frock's smile fades and his shoulders sag.  He duc wheelchair quickly into the Hall of African Mammals.

Two stories high, dark and dramatic.  A very special disp of lions, hippos, wart hogs etc.  In the middle is a larg GORILLA beating its chest.  Frock takes refuge in the dar exhibit.  His wheelchair sits in a quiet corner and we se wipe the back of his hands across his eyes.

Shells and sea life line the walls.  A sign announces the "Mollusks and Our World."  The THIRD GRADE CLASS sweeps i Henry start to sing "Mollusks and Our World" to the tune to Our World", the F.A.O. Schwartz theme song.  Mrs. Beas them the evil eye and Henry whines...
Mrs. Beasley, it's almost time to go and we still haven't seen the dinosaurs!
If you ask me about the dinosaurs once more, I'II strangle you both!
She starts to lecture about horseshoe crabs in a droning Henry and Larry hang back.
(whispers) This room sucks.
She's never going to take us to see the dinosaurs.  That lady said they were on the fourth floor.
Let's ditch and find them ourselves.
They dart off down a side corridor and up a wide stairs.

Larry and Henry emerge and walk wide-eyed among the cases chameleons, tortoises.  High windows light the room.  Out going down.  A woman pushing a child in a stroller exits have the hall to themselves.
Look at this.  A Komodo dragon.
As Larry checks out, the huge, dragon-like reptile, which sunk its Jaws into a stuffed boar.  Henry points to a stu climbing vertically up the side of its case.
Check out this one.  It can walk up walls.

Larry already has his eyes on the far end of the hall whe barricades have been put up to prevent access to the next Painting is in progress.  Scaffolding just begs to be cli runs over and starts up the scaffolding.  Larry hesitates
We're not supposed to go back there.
Chicken.  This is a great short cut.
Henry drops on the other side of the scaffolding and Larr a moment both disappear from sight.

Windowless and dark.  A closed display under maintenance. little stuffed birds line the walls from floor to ceiling cotton poking out of sightless eyes.  Henry and Larry ent down.  Larry's getting scared.
I don't want to go this way.
Don't be a wuss.  Come on.
The boys continue onward more slowly, their footfalls ech silence.

The children are now far from the other tourists and thei Larry is frightened.  The hall takes a sharp dog-leg, end darkened cul-de-sac full of display cases filled with hid masks.  Against the side of the chamber is a barricade of looks much like a wall.  Henry tugs at it and the barrica looks behind.
Hey, there's a secret staircase back here.  Cool.
Henry disappears behind the barricade leaving Larry compl in the dark room with the Shaman masks.
Henry, come back!
Henry doesn't respond.  The lights in the cases throw str Larry starts to sniffle, falls to hiccuping, sits down. little flap of rubber that's coming off the toe of his sn bravado gone.
Henry!  Henry!
No answer.  Larry rises and peeks behind the barricade. circular stair.  It descends into total darkness.  From b strange smell that makes Larry's nose wrinkle.
Henry?
No answer.  Larry puts his first foot on the stair.
Henry!  Come up!  Please!
With no other option but staying alone in the dark, Larry Henry down.
Larry clutches the banister, whispers...
Henry?  Where are you?  Henry?
Larry takes another step.  Another.  And another.  He sto hears SNUFFLING, rather like a large dog.  Larry freezes, cry.
Henry!  Henry!  It smells awful. Answer me!  Are you all right?

Larry can barely see a dim hallway stretching out in two He pauses near the bottom of the stairs, eyes wide, holdi breath.  There appears to be a darker area of SHADOW at t hall.  It's gliding TOWARDS THEM! Suddenly something CLOSES on Larry's leg and he YELPS.  I Henry pulls Larry the rest of the way down the stairs.  T alone together in the darkness.  Henry hisses.
Quiet!
What is it?
I don't know.  But I think it's bad.
They keep their eyes locked on the shape at the end of th they back up, step by step.  Move in as their faces sudde FEAR.  THE BOYS... SCREAM BLOODY MURDER... The sound echo darkness as we...

Margo sits up in the darkness, gasping.  Moonlight cuts a It takes a moment for her to realize that she's had a nig reaches for her light.  As she switches it on, we see a p bedside table.  It shows a group on a mountain in TIBET. several people with their arms slung around each other. a younger MARGO holding hands with JOHN WHITTLESLEY.  The more than friends. ON MARGO... she looks at the photo a moment, then turns o and lies back, alone in her bed.

Yellow crime tape encircles the museum.  Dead leaves swir and the sky is overcast.  Overnight, fall turned to winte of the museum is ringed with police cars.  Margo rides up and pauses, startled at the sight.  We watch as she cross words with one of the officers who motions her to a side wheels her bike under a stone tunnel as we pick up...  A TAXI CAB arriving at the front entrance.  Out steps SPE PENDERGAST.
Margo enters.  The huge hall is taken up by an enormous b from the trunk of a single tree.  Inside it are mannequin Coast Indians.  Milling around are at least twenty COPS. approaches.
ID.
Worried, Margo hands it over.
What's going on?
All employees are to go to the IMAX room for a briefing, Dr. Green.

Several cops go by with tracking dogs.  Margo looks back increasingly uneasy, almost bumps into...  HENRY AND LARRY.  Surprisingly, they are alive and well a MRS. BEASLEY outside an office.  Margo exchanges a look w remembering them from yesterday.  A tentative smile start and Larry don't return it.  Serious and chastened, they d eyes.  Margo continues on. TWO COPS stand outside the door to the rest room, their b to Margo as she approaches.
What was that?  Six?
Lost count.
Margo glances past them to see an OLDER MAN wearing the b NIGHT WATCHMAN, leaning over a sink.  He wipes his mouth. move down to see... THE MAN'S SNEAKERS are soaked in bloo

More cops gather, surrounded by skeletons of primates... monkeys, gorillas.  It's an odd sight.  They all look up as in walks the imposing figure of...  SPECIAL AGENT PENDERGAST.  He turns to a young eager beav BAILEY, flashes his badge.  Bailey straightens to attenti
Could you please take me to the officer in charge?

Pendergast follows Bailey as they descend the rickety old staircase that goes into the bowels of the museum.  The h is narrowand lit by an occasional bare bulb.  The stairwa maze-like set of rooms in the basement.  Everything aroun STREAKED and SPATTERED in BLOOD.  There are trails of it the walls, the overhead light. Several COPS stand guard as DETECTIVE VINCE D'AGOSTA goes area.  He is a round, balding, man with an unmistakable a authority.  A modern knight in shining armor in disguise. deep disguise.  He has on a cheap polyester short sleeved shir is plainly visible underneath.  On his worn plastic belt

Don't touch anything until the S.O.C.  has finished with those stairs.  Keep everyone clear of the perimeter.  I don't want any contamination.  There's an incredible amount of blood evidence down here. We need more light.  Where's the photographer?  Tell him to quit eating donuts, I need him.
As Pendergast enters, D'Agosta looks up at this serious A American in simple black suit, white shirt and dark tie.
Who are you?  The undertaker?
Special Agent Pendergast.  FBI.
Vince D'Agosta.  Am I out?
Not at all.  I think we may be working on the same case.  If so, I could use your help.
The two men shake hands.  They couldn't be more different is an elegant intellectual... D'Agosta a working class sp operates from the gut.  Pendergast gestures to the form o
The body?
What's left of it.
Mind if I have a look?
D'Agosta calls to A POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER who comes down th carrying lights, a donut stuffed in his mouth.
We need light in here, stat.
Where's the head?
D'Agosta points to a lump the size of a bowling ball that corner.
Careful.  That mess on the ground is brains.
Whose footprints?
Night watchman who found the body. Sweet old man.  Been tossing his cookies for over an hour.  Not a likely suspect.

The photographer is finally ready and he floods the dark light.  And now everyone (but not  us ) gets a very clear look at the body. THE PHOTOGRAPHER... spits out his donut.  His eyes roll u in a dead faint.  Just like that.  D'Agosta swallows hard
Woof.
Pendergast looks down, utterly impassive.
Yes, I'd say we're definitely working on the same case.

An old 19th century theater.  Balconies.  Heavy curtains. the theater where Lincoln was shot, with the exception of recent addition, an IMAX SCREEN five stories high.  The r with museum employees, all murmuring anxiously.  Margo si to Frock's wheelchair.  Her face is ashen.
Dr. Frock, I just saw a man back there who'd been wading in blood.
As Greg Kawakita sits in the chair next to Margo...
For once I'm glad you're rumor central.  What in the world is going on?
Someone's been murdered.  Not shot, strangled or stabbed, either.  Torn limb from limb.  There's talk of a psychotic killer or even an animal.
For heaven's sake, Greg, someone's been killed.  Look, it's Cuthbert. Let's hear what really happened.
At this everyone falls silent and IAN CUTHBERT steps forw address the crowd.  He appears drawn and grey.

This has been a tragic and upsetting morning.  I have terrible news for us all.  A member of our security force has been found murdered.  The police have just informed me it was Daniel Beauregard. (murmuring fills the room) Quiet.  Please.  With the help of our head of security, Mr. Ippolito... the museum has been secured.
IPPOLITO... rises in the back and nods to the crowd... He looking, pompous man with shifty eyes.  Right now he's de Overnight, his job is on the line...

The police are satisfied we're in no danger, that we're all perfectly safe.  We've been asked to remain in the Gem Room and be available for questioning for the rest of the day. Obviously, we will all do everything we can to cooperate.  Are there any questions?
Ippolito raises a hand.
The party for the opening of the Superstition Exhibit... I imagine in the light of what's happened it will be pushed back.
No action has been taken yet.  The opening of the exhibit is crucial to the financial health of this museum. So for now, we expect that the Superstition Exhibit will open on schedule, tomorrow night.
Ippolito registers surprise.  The audience buzzes again.
Margo, Dr. Frock and Greg Kawakita enter.  The room is fu spectacular displays of gemstones of every type.  Greg dr over a grey sofa.  Margo leans on a giant geode.
That Cuthbert.  What a piece of work. Someone's dead and all he cares about is his Superstition Exhibit.

He was afraid of himself.  He tried suicide once.  He was ill.  Manic depressive.  He had wild emotional highs and lows.  Not a happy affliction for a scientist.  He'd been revered in our community.  By the end he was a joke.
Tell me about the last expedition. What was he looking for?
A legendary monster called Mbwun.

Yes.  He developed his own theory that he called the Calisto Effect. It held that evolution wasn't always gradual or driven by natural selection.  The environment would sometimes cause sudden and grotesque changes which could result in a "monster species".  It made no sense. But he felt he had evidence that Mbwun was such a monster, living in isolation on the tepui for thousands of years.

It looks more like a bizarre industrial kitchen than anyt Deep stainless steel tanks line one wall.  On the ceiling tanks hang massive pulleys and grappling hooks for the la carcasses.  In a far corner of the workshop is a stainles bearing a DEAD GORILLA.  A pink faced eighty year old man the carcass with sharp tools.  This is DON OSTERBAAN.
Did you ever wonder where we get all our skeletons?  This is the laboratory where animal carcasses are reduced to bones. (to Osterbaan) What's cooking today, Don?
Zebra.
Frock looks into a large maceration tank with Pendergast A zebra carcass can be seen under the muddy surface, its soft tissues falling off.
Man, that's ripe.

Frock now opens the door on a humid closet adjacent to th Inside on a stainless steel table lies the corpse of a fo crawling with BLACK BEETLES which are devouring it.  D'Ag Pendergast watch the grizzly scene, properly impressed.
Dermestid beetles.  The second method of preparing a skeleton, used in Natural History Museums world wide. Bugs are clean and highly efficient. They'll polish that fox off in no time.
As Don casually peels back the gorilla's whole face expos skull...
Want to have a look at a gorilla brain?  Got one right here.
Thanks Don.  We're in a hurry.  Some other time.

More rows of stainless steel doors under hissing steam pi light is dim here, and several bulbs are burned out.  But on the storage rooms are much higher now.  The three men the darkness.  Frock rounds a last corner and wheels to a
This should be it.  Can you read the number?

Pendergast reaches up above them and TAPS THE LIGHT BULB. and they all see the heavy steel door of the storage area jaw drops and his toothpick falls out.  The door has been top to bottom by long, vicious, CLAWS!
Holy shit.
Frock stares in amazement, shaken.  He runs a finger down ruts.
Something tried to get into this room!
And failed.  These doors are solid steel.
This means there must be an animal loose in the museum!
I wouldn't be so sure.
Pendergast takes Frock's keys and opens the door.  It swi oiled hinges.  D'Agosta turns on a light.
They all enter.  Nothing has been disturbed.  The crates middle of the small room, untouched.  Pendergast kneels b that's been opened.
This must be the one that held the statue.  Let's see what else is inside.
Pendergast removes the lid and hands it to D'Agosta, pull DART GUN, SEED PODS, a CARVED STONE.  D'Agosta takes the it.
The lid of this crate is scratched with claw marks, just like the door.
As D'Agosta studies the lid, a brittle, water damaged env out.  D'Agosta picks it up.  The envelope bears an imprin
ARROWS, one silver overlaid with another of GOLD .
Look.  It's some kind of letter.
(excited) May I see that?
D'Agosta hands the letter to Frock.
It's from John.  Those two arrows were his insignia.  It's addressed to Louis Moriarty, a patron who financed his expeditions.
Read it out loud.

"Dear Louis, Tomorrow we go to the south end of the tepui where we'll be in the greatest danger, so I'm sending Carlos back with the crates.  You always believed in me, Louis, even in the darkest days.  So it gives me great pleasure to tell you your faith has been rewarded.  We've made an incredible find.  I enclose a representation of Mbwun.  Note the exaggerated claws, the reptilian attributes, the hints of bipedalia. It's beyond belief, but this statue is accurate.  I know because I've seen the beast."
Frock stops, looks up at D'Agosta and Pendergast.  His fa with the thrill.
Did you hear that?  My God.  He says that Mbwun is real!
(snorts) Pardon my French, but bull shit.
This on top of the scratches... isn't it proof!
I think the scratches were put there to scare us.  Perhaps even lead us to this note.
Pendergast looks out to the dark corridors.
You said John Whittlesley made a study of your blueprints of the museum.
Yes.
Are there any hidden rooms or staircases?  Places where someone could hide?
Not really.  Just the sub-basement.
D'Agosta and Pendergast exchange a look.
Where is that?
I don't know.  It was walled over.  No one's been down there in years.
You said you had plans of the museum.  Could we see them, please?

A series of boxes labeled "PROFESSOR FROCK" sit on the lo small moving van, partially loaded with the contents of F office, sits waiting.  Frock delves through one of the bo Pendergast and D'Agosta look on.

I know they're here somewhere.  It's a good thing we caught the movers in time.  They're nineteen century blueprints from when the museum was built.  I remember the sub-basement was below the regular basement, linked to the city sewer.  I only know about it because it flooded all the way up to the museum during the hurricane of '49.  I lost so many precious books.

Frock continues to unload boxes, scattering things right It's the most amazing assortment of paraphernalia.  A col wildflowers, soil samples, a stuffed owl.  Finally he pul very old blueprints and flashes a triumphant smile.
Eureka.  Who says it doesn't pay to be a pack rat?  Now please be careful with these.  When you're done, I'd like them back.
Visitors scatter as Pendergast enters with D'Agosta, TWO dog handler, JONATHAN HAMM and Jonathan's pair of HUGE BL The deputies are armed with large shotguns.  Pendergast s blueprints as they walk.
How big is the sub-basement?
Apparently it's huge.
I think I should come with you.
We haven't got time.  You have to meet with museum security so we can make a decision about tonight.
Pendergast, Jonathan, his dogs and the deputies make thei industrial set of stairs into the basement.
In a moment they arrive at the site of Beauregard's murde at the bottom of the spiral stairway is still littered wi crime tape, spray paint and the remains of scores of peop in and out.
These plans indicate there's a walled over entrance to the sub- basement right around here.
They move carefully down the dark corridor which we remem time we last saw it with Henry and Larry.  Unknown to Jon Pendergast, the dogs are walking directly towards the spo boys faced the monster.
The dogs are picking up something, Mr. Pendergast.

The dogs start barking in animation, sniffing the wall. studies the blueprints with a flashlight, moves to the sp nothing to be seen.  He shines his flashlight over the wa uneven stucco between two steel beams.  The dogs sniff fu point where the wall meets the floor.  Pendergast moves h the joint between the stucco and the beam, shoves hard. pushes back.  It's a door!
They enter a dank stairwell with brick stairs.  Water dri walls.
What is this?  A dungeon?
Jonathan looks uneasy, double wraps the dogs' leashes aro black-gloved hands.  The two deputies remove their 12 gau shoulders.  Then they all follow the animals, descend dow stairwell.

The place looks like the control room of a nuclear power SECURITY GUARDS monitor a battery of closed-circuit scree is now accompanied by the pompous head of security, IPPOL Ippolito feels D'Agosta is pissing on his territory and h assert control.
This huge police presence tonight isn't necessary, Lieutenant.  You'll just scare people off.  I can handle the security behind scenes with this system.  It's state of the art.
The cops are non-negotiable, Ippolito.  Why don't you just tell me how this space station works.

It's fool proof, basically.  I designed this whole thing myself. Every valuable object in the Museum carries a small electronic chip.  If anything's moved so much as an inch, we get an alarm pinpointing the exact location of the attempted theft.
That's great if you're stopping a burglar.  Not our goal here.  Are there motion detectors?

In every exhibition room.  The museum's divided into five cells. The reception and exhibit are in cell five.  We could arm the motion detectors in cells one to four, then seal the perimeter with our fire doors.

That would leave one exit for hundreds of people.  You'd be violating every fire regulation on the books.  We'll guard the perimeter with my men and engage the motion detectors in the other cells.  One more question.  I see a big hole.  If this entire thing is run by computer, what happens if the power fails?
(snorts) You don't know much about computers, Lieutenant.  There are safeguards built in.  We have back-up systems with redundancies.  There's no way these computers can fail.
Margo, Kawakita and Frock are studying the contents of th
I can't help thinking there's something that Pendergast overlooked.  If the scratches were made by whatever killed Beauregard, it wants something that's in here.
A blow dart.  Seed pods.  A plant press.  Pretty unimpressive stuff.
Let me see the plant press.
Frock opens the plant press and sees a specimen inside.
What is it?

I'm not sure.  As you know, the Kothoga lived outside civilization on the tepui for thousands of years. Species flourished in isolation when man and pollution rendered them extinct.  This could be one of the last remaining samples of an unknown plant.
Whatever it is, it must be common on the tepui.  John used it as packing material.
You're right.
Kawakita lifts out a bit of the fibers, as does Frock.
They're curiously fleshy.
And they smell delicious.
Kawakita TAKES a NIBBLE.
Taste great.
I wouldn't put that in your mouth until we do a chemical analysis, Greg.
I can handle that for you while we're waiting on the G.S.E.
Kawakita rises and exits with some of the plant.
What about those seed pods?  Are they from the same plant?
Frock takes a moment to study them, looks up.
Margo, these aren't seed pods.
What are they?
They're eggs.

Black as night.  The only light comes from the men's flas They're at a crossroads.  Crooked corridors, with arched barely the height of a man stretch in several directions. crouched down, resting with the panting dogs.  The deputi a smoke.  They all look both uneasy and exhausted except Pendergast.  He stares at the blueprints.
Hard to read in this light.  The ink is so faded.
The dogs have lost the scent, Mr. Pendergast.  Maybe we should head back.
Not yet.  Let's try the fork to the left.
The men reluctantly shoulder their shotguns and push on. walk ahead, carelessly nosing the ground.  The flashlight illuminate lime-encrusted, cave-like walls.
This place gives me the creeps.
At this the dogs begin to WHINE.  The HAIR on their backs ridge.  Pendergast turns as a BREEZE stirs his clothes.
They've got something.
Keep the light up.  I can't see.

The dogs strain and pull forward, sniffing the air ahead. raise up their shotguns as they all move deeper into the flashlight beams streak crazily in all directions, barely the gloom.  Suddenly the dogs break into a terrifying BAY bounces off the walls.
Shut them up!
Heel Argo!  Hobbes!  Heel!
The dogs drag Jonathan forward, paying no attention, foam mouth.  Jonathan is now frightened.
They're going crazy!  I need help!
Too late.  As Jonathan tries to grab the collars, one of forward, and the leash slips through Jonathan's hands.
He's loose!  Argo!
Argo BOLTS into the darkness.  The men start after the do the frantic barking which echoes farther and farther in t Pendergast is in the lead.  Suddenly he throws out his ar
Stop!
Holy mother, what is that?
A goatish odor envelops them all.
Smells God-awful.  Like rotten meat.
Argo!  Come!
Quiet!

A SCUFFLING sound of claws dragging on brick is heard fol ROAR.  The men all freeze.  The other dog leaps and twist excitement.  In the confusion it also breaks free!  It te first dog, disappearing into the darkness.  Now Jonathan
No!  Hobbes!
The deputies are terrified, retreat.  The darkness is sti claustrophobic.  The flashlights are small help.  Penderg remains dead calm.  His voice is cool and commanding.
Forget the dogs.  You two, get back here.  Don't point that gun at me.

The deputies regain control and follow Pendergast's order into position, pump their shotguns and aim them down the echoing darkness ahead of them, the barking falters and s There is a moment of silence, then a terrible, unearthly deputies quail, frozen in their tracks.  Jonathan leaps f
Argo!  Hobbes!
Get back!  Now!

At that moment a SHAPE hurtles at them from the darkness! in terror.  There are two stunning BLASTS from the shotgu FLASHES of light accompanied by a deafening roar.  The ru and dies and there's an intense silence, followed by a so
You shot my dog!
Hobbes lies five feet from them, a black shadow of death. kneels by the dog, tears in his eyes.  Down the animals s
My dog...
(stammers) He was coming right at me...
In the distance they can hear a terrified howl.  It's the hurt or frightened.  It's a pitiful sound.
Let's get out of here!
I'm not going anywhere!  Not without my dog!
Pendergast grabs at Jonathan who slips from his grasp.  J back down the hallway calling desperately.
Hobbes!
Get back!
Jonathan shakes his head no.
There's something out there!  Let's go get it now!  That's why we came down here, isn't it?
(to the deputies) He's right.  Follow me.
But the two deputies are terrified.  They cling to the wa backwards, sheer horror in their eyes.
No way.  I say we get help.  A lot more guns.
I'm ordering you!  Cover me!
We'll cover you from here!

Jonathan is disappearing in front of them.  Pendergast ha Grim faced, he pulls his Colt .45 Anaconda from a shoulde It's a narrow and evil-looking gun.  From a pocket comes 255 grain wadcutter and 147 grain FMJ flatnose ammunition up, goes after Jonathan, who's no longer in sight.  Pende down a long, sloping hallway into cavernous blackness ahe bottom Pendergast stops.  He has to stoop down as he goes archway and into...
A dark stream of water runs between concrete walls with t off from all sides.  It appears to be part of the sewer s cowers in a corner.  Jonathan moves to his side.
Look.  It's Hobbes!  He's all right.
Come on.  Let's get back to the others.  We can't leave them alone.
It's alright.  I can tell by the way the dog's acting that whatever was out there is gone.  What is this place?
Not on the map.  Looks like it connects with the city sewer.
Pendergast calls back down the tunnel for the deputies.
We're coming back!

The words go unanswered.  From the hall comes a loud REPO shotguns, blasting desperately.  Something flies up all a the sound echoes.  BATS! Pendergast and Jonathan shield themselves from the flurry wings.  Finally the animals settle and Pendergast and Jon a look.  The silence is filled by a soft RUMBLING SOUND. together, waiting.  Pendergast points his gun at the hall to the deputies.  A ridge of hair on the dog's back rises growls.
Identify yourself!  Who's there?

No answer.  The rumbling continues, growing louder.  Then appears.  It comes rolling out of the hallway, bounces in and stops.  Pendergast shines his light on...  DEPUTY ONE'S HEAD!  The mouth is open wide in terror.  Ac is a vicious claw mark.
Oh... my... God!
(hisses) Quiet.
And now they hear a GUT WRENCHING SHRIEK that's abruptly followed by a second rumbling sound!  Jonathan grabs Pend shirt, panicked.
Stay calm.
They head quietly for the exit at the other end of room w slope up.  After they're gone a few moments the head of D rolls to a stop.
Cabs and limousines tangle outside the west entrance.  A SPOTLIGHT is now turned on.  Elegantly dressed men in din and women in gowns rush to get out of the pelting rain, u jousting.
Cuthbert's putting on his tux.  He adjusts the cummerbund happily as D'Agosta looks on.  D'Agosta paces, highly agi worried.
I'm telling you, something's wrong. I still haven't heard from Pendergast.  I think you should call it off.
It's too late now.  Guests are arriving.  The Mayor's car is pulling up.
I'll go down and speak to him.
(irritated) You haven't got the authority.  Only Pendergast can pull the plug.
Pendergast may be in trouble.  Don't you understand?  He still hasn't come back.  It's been over three hours --
He'll be back.  Relax.  We're in good shape.  Your security is air tight. There've been no more incidents, nothing suspicious.  There's no reason to call off the opening now.

Resounding with the echoes of several hundred expensive s the marble expanse and heading down the rows of palm tree the Hall of Heavens.  The palms themselves are festooned and violet lights.  Somewhere inside, an invisible band i York, New York".  An army of waiters in white tie thread through the guests carrying large silver platters crowded champagne glasses.  Cuthbert enters and crosses to meet T THE MAYOR'S WIFE.  Photographers step forward and flashbu
Food is out.  Hundreds of tables are set with black linen Decorations have a dark, haunted house theme.  A hum of a up past the vast Corinthian columns into the circular dom
An explosive sneeze rattles the beakers and dislodges the specimens.  Margo interrupts her work at the computer to tissue as Frock looks on.
What kind of egg is it?
It's reptilian.
Like the claw.
(cautious) Let's not jump to conclusions.  This egg could belong to any number of reptiles, Dr. Frock.

(excited) Come on, Margo.  We're on the verge of something huge.  Let's consider the possibility, just the three of us, alone in this room.  What if John was right.  I mean, what if?  And he sent back an egg of his monster in the crates.  When it got to the museum, it hatched.

Several problems with that theory. For one thing, this egg is intact. For another, according to Pendergast, the crates were shipped here on a boat.  Everyone on board was killed like Beauregard.  If the thing hatched in mid-ocean, where did it go?
Frock has no answer.  Greg gestures to his computer scree
I guess you're not interested in this plant anymore, but the chemical analysis is done.  Frock reads the computer over Greg's shoulder.

"Genus: Unknown.  Family: Unknown. Order: Unknown.  Phylum: Unknown. Cripes, Margo, what did you give me? Is this an animal or one funky shrub?" (to Kawakita) I see you've been programming the computer vocabulary again.
(points to a hexagonal symbol) Look at this.  An ambyloid reovirus protein.  That explains why the computer's confused.  The plant's infected with a virus.
That's not so unusual.  Many plants carry viruses.  Like the burls on Maple trees.

But a virus normally codes for other viruses.  This one's making human and animal proteins.  Listen to this. (reads) "Glycotetraglycine collagenoid. Weinstein's tropic hormone.  4- monoxytocin supressin hormone."
These plant fibers are loaded with hormones!
What kind of hormones?
Kawakita pulls a heavy book from the shelf.  The Encyclop Biochemistry, thumbs to a page and reads.
4-monoxytocin is... "A hormone secreted by the human hypothalamus gland."
Try Weinstein's tropic hormone.
The tension is rising in the room.  Frock takes the book, one up, reads silently and removes his glasses.
A hormone secreted by the human thalamus gland.
Kawakita and Frock look puzzled.  Margo rises in agitatio
This is it.  This is what he, or it... is after!  The plant has high concentrations of the same hormones found in minute quantities in the human brain!
So what?
Pendergast told me the killer extracts and eats the hypothalamus and thalamus of the victim's brains!
(pales) Eats them?
Yes.  Whatever killed Beauregard may have lived on this plant.  When the crates were put in secure storage, they were out of reach.  The killer couldn't get them, so it got the next best thing.
Beauregard's head.
There's a moment of stunned silence.  Then a LOUD BUZZER jump.
It's all right.  That means the G.S.E.  has finished analyzing the claw DNA.  Greg, you go find Pendergast and Lieutenant D'Agosta now.
Kawakita tears up the dark stairs.  He turns a corner and JUMPS OUT at him.  He almost screams.  It's a DRUNK.
Hey, where 'za little boys room?
Down that hallway.  But don't stay long.  You don't want to be here alone.
Margo and Frock enter and huddle over a sheaf of papers t printer has spit out.

All right, assuming the program is accurate, this is a description of the animal with that claw. (she reads) "Species unidentified.  Genus: unidentified.  Phylum unknown.  Male, weight in excess of 240 kg.  Brain capacity, 900 centimeters." That means it's highly intelligent. "Quadrupedal."
Quadrupedal!  The other name for Mbwun.  "He Who Walks on All Fours."
Margo and Frock exchange a look.  Holy shit.  Margo swall reading.

"Nocturnal.  External hair and bony plates.  Locomotor speed 60-70 kilometers.  Reduced optic chiasm"...  poor eyesight.  "External mucoid nasal glands,"... very keen scent...  "Morphological characteristics: Highly robust.  Aggressiveness: extreme."
So the claw came from a huge creature with a preternatural sense of smell and poor eyesight that hunts at night.
With the intelligence of a human being, the speed of a greyhound, and the strength of a grizzly bear.
(a long moment) Margo, what you've just described is a killing machine.

And it's hungry.  It's been two days since it's eaten.  There are five hundred people arriving right now. The animal hunts at night and it has a keen sense of smell!  All those people in one enclosed space...
It's like ringing the dinner bell.

The crowd is now packed into the rotunda as the MAYOR cut ribbon across the entrance to the exhibit and everyone ap Cuthbert is by the mayor's side.  He steps forward and ra for quiet.  The crowd falls silent.
Thank you everyone and welcome. We're glad all of you were willing to brave the inclement weather to be with us tonight.  Our special thanks to his honor, the mayor and his lovely wife.
The Mayor takes a bow.  More applause.

Some people have questioned whether a superstition exhibit belongs in a Museum of Science.  Spells, incantations, demons, magic... these are forces that defy the natural laws.  Superstition provides answers to the great questions based on fear.  Science provides answers to the great questions based on truth. Science and superstition, then, are polar opposites.  Mortal enemies, if you will.  And that is why we are here tonight.  We have come to learn more about the enemy, and thus to bring about its defeat.  For every good, there is an evil, for every dark, a light.  And so tonight... my friends, I give you ignorance, terror, unreasoning fear, pure evil. (smiles, gestures to the exhibit) Have a great time.
Everyone laughs, applauds again as Cuthbert and the Mayor inside.  Kawakita is making his way over to D'Agosta.  Th entrance is incredible.
Lieutenant!  It's me.
What is it?
Dr. Green has to see you!
Got my hands full here.
It's important.  Please.  You have to come!  Pendergast, too.  She's found out something.
D'Agosta pulls out his walkie talkie.
McNitt?  D'Agosta here.

Officer McNitt stands in the corner of the computer room, neon light.  Running the security system is GEORGE, your nerd.  Multiple screens all over show various rooms in th are empty with the exception of those showing the exhibit these, the crowds can be seen entering the various rooms. his walkie talkie.
Yeah Lieutenant?  I'm here.
I'm heading to the Evolutionary Bio labs.  Any sign of Pendergast?
Not yet.
At this moment a NOISE comes from the adjoining room.  Mc SWIVELS.  It's a LOUD THUMP.
Hold on Lieutenant. (to George) What was that?
Probably just something wrong with the air conditioning.  There's a shit load of electrical rooms back there.
George is playing an elaborate computer game and not payi McNitt returns to his walkie talkie as the THUMP comes ag looks distinctly nervous.
Lieutenant?  There's something wrong in the computer room.
Goddamn it.  I'll get Ippolito and send him up.
George rises.
You're over-reacting.  Sounds like the air conditioning to me.
McNitt watches uneasily as George opens the door, disappe next room.
D'Agosta turns to Kawakita who waits, shifting from foot
Damn.  There's some kind of problem in the computer room.  I have to go get Ippolito.  You wait here.
D'Agosta heads into the exhibit before Kawakita can prote

We see various cuts of people as they move into the diffe TEENAGE GIRL (LAUREN) and her FATHER (DAVID) examine a li rotting European style coffin, complete with corpse.  A w gentleman (DR. POUND), leans on his cane as he looks at a primitive medicine practiced with implements that look li tools. Cuthbert and Ippolito are at the head of a press of peopl MAYOR and HIS WIFE a guided tour.
Here we have a very rare sacrificial table from Mesoamerica.  The priests would kill the victim on this slab, cut out the heart and eat it while it was still beating.
I could use one of these things in City Hall.
Cuthbert laughs right on cue.  They pass a Congo power fi bulging eye sockets and torso riddled with sharp nails. recoil from it, looking repulsed.  The MAYOR's WIFE sees distressed.
You're letting kids see this?  I should think they'd have nightmares.
Kid will love it.  They're our target audience.  Nothing here is as violent as what they see on T.V.
They pass a MUMMY dripping in BLOOD.  The Mayor gestures
I don't know.  That could be a little over the top.  It's not even scientific.  Mummies don't bleed.

Cuthbert's smile fades as he sees the mummy. CLOSE ON... the MAYOR'S WHITE CUFF as he extends his hand the mummy.  The pristine white of his cuff is suddenly co falling RED DROP OF BLOOD. Cuthbert sees it.  So does the Mayor and Ippolito.  They another DROP OF BLOOD falls right on Cuthbert's face.  An droplet falls on THE MAYOR'S WIFE'S white bosom, exposed cut dress!
Oh... my... God...

THEIR POV... above the mummy's head, the top of the case exposing a ceiling crawling with steam pipes and ductwork watch, and the cuff of a blue shirt protrude over the edg case.  A small icicle of blood hangs from the middle fing another drop FALLS. CUTHBERT SCREAMS AT THE TOP OF HIS LUNGS!  Conscious of t factor, Ippolito yells.
Quiet everyone!
But it's too late.  The room is packed with people.  And himself is just pushing through the door as another woman
There's a body up there!

A ripple of fear goes over the faces in the room, titters wonder if it's a joke.  At that moment from the darkness ceiling buckles and something FALLS! It's OFFICER DOYLE'S HEADLESS TORSO, dripping blood! UTTER PANDEMONIUM breaks loose!  The close space ECHOES w and shouts.  People claw at each other, stumbling despera get to the door.  A YOUNG WOMAN falls and D'Agosta runs t her from being trampled in the stampede.
McNitt is staring in horror at the remote camera images s chaos in the exhibition, the faces registering blind fear start going off all over the place.  McNitt calls out...
George!  Get out here, now!

McNitt looks around, desperate.  But George still isn't h to the electrical room is still open.  The ceiling shudde thundering feet.  McNitt can hear distant SCREAMS!  It's hair on the back of his neck.  He calls out.
George!  Where are you?
No answer.  He moves to the open door, a new fear in his inside.

BLACKNESS.  McNitt can't find a light switch.  He stays i silhouetted by light from the computer room.  With shakin pumps a slug into the chamber of his shotgun.  There's a gurgling sound.  It's McNitt's stomach.  He silences it,
Hey you?  George!  Damn it.  Where are you?  No response.
McNitt edges into the darkened rooms.  The first one's em the next.
George!  We've got an emergency!  Are you here?

Suddenly there's a HUGE THUMP and a scuttling to his left terrifying sound!  McNitt drops to his knees and pumps th each with a light and a deafening blast!  A SHOWER OF SPA of flame licks upwards, illuminating the room with orange HUGE DARK SHAPE ducks out the door!
Oh God.  Oh God!

Gunpowder hangs in the air like a blue fog.  On the far w metal box is smoking from three large, ragged holes!  Wit pop, an electrical arc slices across the ruined box, foll crackling and a shower of sparks.  McNitt ducks back into room, slams the door and locks it, breathing hard.
Every single screen flickers and dims.  But to McNitt's r has returned.  He is sitting with his back to the doorway
George!  I saw something in there!  I fired but I think I missed it!
George remains still, his back to McNitt, staring at the on the flickering screen.
George, for Chrissake answer me!
McNitt puts a hand on George's shoulder, swivels his chai ON GEORGE... His face ripped off.
ON THE CENTRAL SWITCHING BOX... sparking and shorting as

head_text.subj: CLAWED ARM SWIPES IT OFF THE WALL

text: Everyone pours out of the exhibit, running for the door l Rotunda.  People are getting trampled.  It's a terrible c Tables over-turned everywhere.  Food scatters to the floo pushes his way out of the exhibit, crosses to Kawakita, w appalled.  Above, the chandeliers are flickering.
What happened?!
There's a dead body in the exhibit! People are panicking, trampling each other trying to get out.
Ippolito runs over to join them.
What the hell is going on?!
Above them THE LIGHTS dim again and come back on.
The whole system is shutting down! We have to get out quickly before the fire doors fall!
What doors?
I told you!  They seal off all the cells.  They were designed to fall automatically in a system failure --
You said the system couldn't fail!
